concern: I’m going to get paid anyway it’s just my PI will have to pay me less. I’d get a pittance monthly and then semesterly I’d get the bulk of the money. I’d have to file taxes quarterly. The end of this week, the week before the grant is due, my PI, co-mentor and I will meet to discuss if I have enough useable preliminary data to submit in April or if I’d have to wait until August. I’ve spent so much energy working on this grant since Feb. It’s consumed my life. I’ve skipped social plans and club rehearsals. After my birthday in march I worked 13 days straight only to hear that I need more data/ my data needed to be analyzed in a different way. What’s the point of this if the only thing I get from it is a shiny bullet point on a resume? I’m feeling jaded. The other third year in my lab (with a really good project and tons of prelim data) got a borderline score so he has no idea if he will get funded or not.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind or any concerns you may have. I'm here to listen and support you in a safe and non-judgmental space.
Thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed and kinda jaded with all the work I’ve been pouring into this grant, and it’s like, for what, you know?
That sounds really frustrating. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when your hard work doesn't seem to be leading anywhere.

Yeah, it’s just been a lot, and I’m starting to question if all this stress is even worth it. Like, I’m grinding so hard, and I’m not sure what I’m really getting out of it besides maybe something to put on my resume.

It sounds like you're feeling undervalued and unfulfilled, despite all the effort you're putting into this grant. I can imagine how disheartening that must be, especially when you're giving it your all and not seeing the desired results.
Yeah, exactly, it’s like I’m running on empty and still not getting anywhere that feels meaningful. I just keep wondering if I’m wasting my time on something that might not even pan out.

It's clear that you're at a crossroads, feeling torn between the effort you're investing and the sense of purpose you're searching for. It sounds like you're questioning whether the potential outcome is worth the current emotional toll. Can you share what keeps you motivated to continue with the grant, even when it feels this way?

Honestly, I think what keeps me going is the hope that this could open some doors for me down the line, even if it’s just a small step. I also don’t want to let my PI down after all the time and resources they’ve put into me, you know?

It sounds like you're driven by a combination of hope for future opportunities and a sense of responsibility to your PI. That's a lot of weight to carry, and it's clear you're doing your best to balance your own needs with the expectations of others. I wonder, what would it be like to imagine a future where this grant does pan out and those doors do open?

Honestly, imagining a future where this grant works out feels both exciting and kinda far-off. Like, I can picture having that achievement under my belt, maybe getting some recognition or a better shot at a job or fellowship, but right now it just feels like a distant dream with all the hurdles I’m facing.

It's inspiring to hear how you're holding onto that vision of a future where the grant pays off, even with the challenges you're facing right now. What would it mean for you to start bridging that gap between the distant dream and the present moment, step by step?

I guess it would mean breaking things down into smaller, manageable pieces instead of feeling overwhelmed by the whole process. Like, maybe focusing on just getting through this meeting about my data this week, and not worrying so much about the bigger picture right now, you know?

That sounds like a wise approach, taking it one step at a time and focusing on what you can control right now. What if we explore some specific strategies that might help you stay grounded and focused as you prepare for this meeting and move forward with the grant?
Yeah, I’d really appreciate that. I’m feeling so scattered right now, and having some concrete ways to stay on track would help me not spiral into worrying about everything at once.

One strategy could be to create a checklist of tasks leading up to the meeting, prioritizing them based on importance and urgency. Another idea is to schedule regular check-ins with yourself or a trusted colleague to review progress and address any concerns as they arise. Lastly, consider setting aside dedicated time each day for focused work on the grant, minimizing distractions during that time. Which of these strategies resonates most with you?

Honestly, the checklist idea really clicks with me because I’m the kind of person who feels better when I can see what needs to be done in front of me. I think starting with that could help me organize my headspace and not feel like I’m drowning in a million things at once.

That's a great choice! The checklist can serve as a visual roadmap, helping you stay on track and make steady progress without getting bogged down by the bigger picture. What specific tasks do you think should be on that checklist to help you feel prepared for the meeting and move closer to your goal?

I think I’d start with stuff like reviewing my prelim data one more time to make sure I’ve got all the key points ready to discuss, and maybe jotting down some questions or concerns I wanna bring up with my PI and co-mentor. Also, probably adding a task to double-check any analysis they wanted done differently, just to feel confident I’m not missing anything before we sit down.

It's great to see you've identified specific tasks that will help you feel prepared for the meeting and move closer to your goal. Remember, the checklist is a tool to help you stay organized and focused, so don't hesitate to adjust it as needed. Also, don't forget to celebrate your progress along the way, no matter how small. You've made significant strides in managing your stress and tackling this project, and that's something to be proud of.

Thanks, I really appreciate the reminder to celebrate the small wins—it’s easy to forget that when I’m so focused on the end goal. So, before we wrap up, do you have any quick tips on how to keep myself from overthinking while I’m working through this checklist?

Absolutely! One strategy you could try is setting a timer for each task on your checklist. When the timer goes off, take a short break to stretch, move around, or do something that takes your mind off the task at hand. This can help break up the monotony of the work and give your mind a chance to reset. Additionally, try to reframe your thoughts when you catch yourself overthinking. Instead of focusing on potential negative outcomes, remind yourself that you're making progress and that each task completed brings you closer to your goal. Lastly, consider practicing mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, to help calm your mind and reduce stress.

Thanks for those ideas—I think setting a timer and taking breaks could really help me stay grounded. Do you think starting with just 5-minute breaks would be enough, or should I aim for longer ones to really step away?
